author: Lucy Potter
title: Influenza ‘immunity gene’ revealed at British Science Festival could protect us all from severe flu symptoms
text:
Have you ever wondered why infections can cause some people to become severely ill, while others get away with the odd sniffle, and some don’t get sick at all ?
Researchers from Cambridge believe it could all be down to our genes .
Speaking at the British Science Festival in Bradford today, Professor Paul Kellam, Viral Genomics lead at the Sanger Institute, said: “the IFITM3 gene is fundamentally important”.
He explained that it could actually prevent viruses from getting into our cells in the first place.
There are different versions of the gene and those of us who carry the ‘at risk’ variant are four to five times more likely to develop severe flu when exposed to a virus, compared to the rest of the population.
These findings provide huge potential for developing antiviral drugs in the future.

Rex Suffering from flu is affected by your genes, according to the latest research
If you block the breakdown of IFITM3 in cells, you can increase the antiviral effects.
Professor Kellam says: “It’s all about raising barriers and giving the virus a bit more of a hurdle to get over”.
Although it will take 5-10 years before these findings translate into new drug discoveries, faster implications are also possible, including better use of the flu vaccine.
The influenza vaccination is currently offered to specific groups in the UK, such as the elderly or those with underlying health problems.
But Professor Kellam says a superior way of prioritising the vaccine is based on an individual’s genes, which can now tell us whether they should receive the jab or not.
"As the UK embarks on sequencing 100,000 individuals, we are going to find a number who have this variant. And if we know that these individuals are more likely to develop severe flu, that information is actionable and relevant,” he explained.
Aggressive therapy But the utility of these findings aren’t restricted to vaccination and drug development. They may also have an immediate impact in emergency healthcare settings.
Professor Kellam explained in an outbreak situation, “when you have lots of people sitting in the waiting room coughing and spluttering and testing positive for the flu, how do you predict which one you need to worry about more than others?”
This variant predicts that you are at greater risk of requiring steroids and are more likely to need ventilation quicker.
Getty No more excuses for man flu
Therefore rapid genetic testing gives clinicians information, which will enable them to start more aggressive therapy for affected individuals.
He said, “It would be interesting to see how clinicians would use that information if they knew before the deterioration of the patient.”
It is clear that the benefits of this research could transform the way we fight viruses.
And Professor Kellam has set a precedent for how you might find other target genes in the future.
The IFITM3 gene is just the beginning. He said, “there are bound to be more genes out there”.
